Thanks Mike that helps, one question though.  You say, "So, use PUT to
do a=
 'partial update' of a resource".  Did you mean to say POST because
this co=
ntradicts your first sentence where you say you have to send the
complete d=
ata when using PUT.
 
Josh

	-----Original Message-----
	From: S. Mike Dier=
ken [mailto:mdierken@...] 
	Sent: Wednesday, January 08, 2003 12:53=
 PM
	To: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
	Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] POST vs.=
 PUT
	
	
	
	----- Original Message -----
	From: <josh.knowles@worldwidepack=
ets.com>
	
	>
	> I want to modify only the name for the resource located
	>=
 at /addressbook/000001, do I POST the changes to the name or
do I
	> PUT t=
hem.  Also, do I need to PUT the entire record or just
the
	> changes?
	
	I=
f you use PUT you need to send the complete data for the
resource - which I=

	think is messed up in the protocol but I'm not a protocol guy
(there are
=
	reasons like caching,etc that may require this behavior).
	So, use PUT to =
do a 'partial update' of a resource. You could
also define a
	more fine-gra=
ined resource and PUT to that...
	
	-- option 1 : partial update via POST -=
-
	POST /addressbook/0001 HTTP/1.1
	Content-Type: text/xml
	Content-Length:=
 nnnn
	
	<contact>
	<name>bob</name>
	<phone>425-555-1212</phone>
	<email>b=
ob@...</email>
	</contact>
	
	
	-- option 2 : fine-grained update via=
 PUT --
	PUT /addressbook/0001;email HTTP/1.1
	Content-Type: text/xml
	Cont=
ent-Length: nnnn
	
	<email>bob@...</email>
	
	
	To unsubscribe from t=
his group, send an email to:
	rest-discuss-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com
	
	
=
	
	Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of
Service <htt=
p://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/> .
